every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way."** > -- Leo Tolstoy ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](images/07-package/tidydata.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: - Each **variable** must have its own **column**. - Each **observation** must have its own **row**. - Each **value** must have its own **cell**. (match the corresponding row observation and column variable) ## Tidy Data (Data Matrix) > **"Tidy datasets are all alike, but every messy dataset is messy in its own way."** > -- Hadley Wickham ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](images/07-package/tidydata.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: - Each **variable** must have its own **column**. - Each **observation** must have its own **row**. - Each **value** must have its own **cell**. (match the corresponding row observation and column variable) ::: notes - Remember in this course we are working on the so-called tidy data. - One of the goals of tidyverse is to make our data tidy. - So before we actually get into tidyverse, Let's define tidy data first. - **"Tidy datasets are all alike, but every messy dataset is messy in its own way."** - Tidy data require that + Each **variable** must have its own **column**. (name-value match) + Each **observation** must have its own **row**. **The observation** could be human being or any object observed in the data set. A row corresponds to an observation. + Each **value** must have its own **cell**. ::: ## Why Tidy Data? 1. Each variable must have its own column. 2. Each observation must have its own row. 3. Each value must have its own cell. . . . - Advantages of tidy data: + If you store all data in a tidy way, you only need to learn the tools that work with them. + Placing variables in columns allows Râ€™s *vectorised* nature to shine. That makes transforming tidy data feel natural. . . . - Practical instructions: > **Put each dataset in a data frame.** > **Put each variable in a column.** ::: notes - These three rules are interrelated; it's impossible to only satisfy two of the three. - Remember, **"Tidy datasets are all alike, but every messy dataset is messy in its own way."** - Remember, R prefer vectorized programming style. If each variable corresponds to a column vector, it is easy to transform variables using vectorised functions. - We will learn how to make our data tidy using **tidyr**, **dplyr** and other packages in **Data Wrangling** weeks. ::: ## ::: {.question} What makes this data not tidy? ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Source: [Army Air Forces Statistical Digest, WW II](https://www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/AAF/StatDigest/aafsd-3.html)](images/07-package/hyperwar-airplanes-on-hand.png){fig-align='center' width=90%} ::: ::: ::: notes - Here shows an example of non-tidy data set. - This is a data set is about aircraft during WWII 1939 to 1945. - You can see that we have some merge cell showing year, for example 1939 and 1940, saying that the rows come after those belong to that year. - But if we were to make this data tidy, we would actually have another column called year, and that column would indicate the values like 1939. - And that would be repeated for each row. - So we don;t want these merge cells in what we call in a tidy data set. - Some non-tidy data can be visually appealing for purposes of communicating. - But when we are working with data and analyzing data, we want this sort of information to be stored in its own column. - And you can see we also have some merge cells for historical events, like Germany invaded Poland. - That might be important when we are visualizing data. - And we should think about if these history events are parts of our analysis. If yes, we need to create one or more columns for those events. If they are just for annotation, and not important in our analysis or modeling, we might actually ignore them. ::: ## :::{.question} What makes this data not tidy? :::

Right? - df[, 1, drop=FALSE] ::: ## Subsets of Tibbles Are Tibbles :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} - [`[]` always returns another tibble.]{.green} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} df_tbl <- tibble(x = 1:2, y = 2:1, z = LETTERS[1:2]) df_tbl[, 1] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 Ã— 1 x 1 1 2 2 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} df_tbl[1] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 Ã— 1 x 1 1 2 2 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center" highlight.output='true'} ```{.r .cell-code} class(df_tbl[, 1]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "tbl_df" "tbl" "data.frame" ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} class(df_tbl[1]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "tbl_df" "tbl" "data.frame" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.fragment} - [`$` and `[[]]` return a vector.]{.green} ::: {.cell layout-align="center" highlight.output='true'} ```{.r .cell-code} df_tbl$x ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 2 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} class(df_tbl$x) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "integer" ``` ::: :::
::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} df_tbl[[1]] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 2 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} class(df_tbl[[1]]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] "integer" ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: :::: ::: notes - Tibbles are quite strict about subsetting ::: ## Tibbles Never Do Partial Matching :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} - [Data frames do **partial matching**]{.green} - *Treat name "a" as "abc"!* ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} (df <- data.frame(abc = 1)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` abc 1 1 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} df$a ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 1 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.gragment} - [Tibbles **never do** partial matching]{.green} - *Name "a" cannot be recognized!* ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} (tib <- tibble(abc = 1)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 1 Ã— 1 abc 1 1 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} tib$a ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: Unknown or uninitialised column: `a`. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` NULL ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: :::: ## Tibbles Can Have Complex Entries :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} - [**Data frame**: Columns can't be defined using other created variables.]{.green} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} data.frame(x = 1:5, y = 1:5, z = x + 3) # object 'x' not found ``` ::: - [**Tibble**: Allow to refer to created variables.]{.green} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} tibble(x = 1:5, y = 1:5, z = x + 3) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 Ã— 3 x y z 1 1 1 4 2 2 2 5 3 3 3 6 4 4 4 7 5 5 5 8 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.fragment} - [**Data frame**: Columns need to be atomic vectors.]{.green} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} data.frame(id = c(1, 2, 3), func = c(mean, median, sd)) # function can't be in a data.frame ``` ::: - [**Tibble**: Elements can be lists or functions.]{.green} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} tibble(id = c(1, 2, 3), func = c(mean, median, sd)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 Ã— 2 id func 1 1 2 2 3 3 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: :::: ::: notes - Columns need to be atomic vectors of numbers, strings, or logical values - Can have more complex objects, such as lists or functions. ::: # {background-color="#A7D5E8" background-image="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rstudio/hex-stickers/master/PNG/pipe.png" background-size="30%"} ::: {.left}

Pipe Operator

::: ## Pipes - The pipe `%>%` comes from the **magrittr** package of **tidyverse**. . . . - R (4.1+) has *native base pipe operator* ` |> `. Tools > Global Options > Code ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](images/07-package/native-pipe.png){fig-align='center' width=60%} ::: ::: :::{.callout-note} :::{style="font-size: 1.2em;"} For simple cases `|>` and `%>%` behave identically. The base pipe is recommended because we can use ` |> ` anywhere anytime in R, even we don't use tidyverse. ::: ::: ::: notes https://r4ds.hadley.nz/data-transform.html#sec-the-pipe ::: ## What and How to Use Pipe - To add the pipe, use keyboard shortcut `Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + M` - The pipe *sends* *the result of the left side* of the pipe to be the **first argument** of the function *on the right side* of the pipe. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](images/07-package/pipe.png){fig-align='center' width=50%} ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} 16 |> sqrt() |> log2() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} log2(sqrt(16)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} ## We can define other arguments as if the first argument is already defined 16 |> sqrt() |> log(base = 2) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 2 ``` ::: ::: ## Why Pipe Operator? - Nested vs. Sequential-piped - More natural and easier-to-read structure ::: small ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Source: https://www.andrewheiss.com/](images/07-package/pipe_example.png){fig-align='center' width=100%} ::: ::: ::: ::: notes - Nested vs. Sequential-piped - Writing it out using pipes give it a more natural and easier-to-read structure. - You can think about the following sequence of actions - wake up, get out of bed, get dressed, and leave house. - Expressed as a set of nested functions in R would look like - Writing it out using pipes give it a more natural and easier to read structure (if you think so) - Like if-else statements, people don't like too many nested layers. We can easily get lost about what is actually doing. - Using pipe operator, we have a clear sequential order, and all the actions or functions will be shown at the beginning of each line, making the code easier to read. ::: ## :::::{.lab} **08-Tibbles and Pipes** In **lab.qmd** `## Lab 8` section, - Compare and contrast the following operations on a `data.frame` and equivalent `tibble`. What are the differences? :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .my_class500 .cell-code} df <- data.frame(abc = 1:2, xyz = c("a", "b")) # list method df$x df[[2]] df["xyz"] df[c("abc", "xyz")] # matrix method df[, 2] df[, "xyz"] df[, c("abc", "xyz")] ``` ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .my_class500 .cell-code} tib <- tibble(abc = 1:2, xyz = c("a", "b")) # list method tib$x tib[[2]] tib["xyz"] tib[c("abc", "xyz")] # matrix method tib[, 2] tib[, "xyz"] tib[, c("abc", "xyz")] ``` ::: ::: :::: - Use ` |> ` to first select last 12 rows of `iris` data set using `tail()`, then provides summary statistics on its columns using `summary()`. ::::: # {background-color="#ffde57" background-image="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/ed/Pandas_logo.svg" background-size="50%"} ::: {.left}

Pandas

::: ## Pandas - Like **tidyverse** in R, **pandas** is a Python library that provides data structures, manipulation and analysis tools for data science. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} import numpy as np import pandas as pd ``` ::: - A Pandas Series is like a *column vector* in a data frame. - It is a one-dimensional array holding data *of any type*. ## Pandas Series from a List ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} # import pandas as pd a = [1, 7, 2] s = pd.Series(a) print(s) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 0 1 1 7 2 2 dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} print(s[0]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 1 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} ## index used as naming s = pd.Series(a, index = ["x", "y", "z"]) print(s) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` x 1 y 7 z 2 dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} print(s["y"]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 7 ``` ::: ::: ## Pandas Series from a Dictionary ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} grade = {"math": 99, "stats": 97, "cs": 66} s = pd.Series(grade) print(s) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` math 99 stats 97 cs 66 dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} grade = {"math": 99, "stats": 97, "cs": 66} ## index used as subsetting s = pd.Series(grade, index = ["stats", "cs"]) print(s) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` stats 97 cs 66 dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: . . . ::: {.question} How do we create a named vector in R? ::: . . . ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} grade <- c("math" = 99, "stats" = 97, "cs" = 66) ``` ::: ## Pandas Data Frame - Create a data frame from a dictionary ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} data = {"math": [99, 65, 87], "stats": [92, 48, 88], "cs": [50, 88, 94]} df = pd.DataFrame(data) print(df) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` math stats cs 0 99 92 50 1 65 48 88 2 87 88 94 ``` ::: ::: . . . - Row and column names ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} df.index = ["s1", "s2", "s3"] df.columns = ["Math", "Stat", "CS"] df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Math Stat CS s1 99 92 50 s2 65 48 88 s3 87 88 94 ``` ::: ::: ## Subsetting Columns :::{.callout-warning} :::{style="font-size: 1.1em;"} - In Python, `[]` returns *Series*, `[[]]` returns *DataFrame*! - In R, `[]` returns *tibble*, `[[]]` returns *vector*! ::: ::: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} ## Series df["Math"] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` s1 99 s2 65 s3 87 Name: Math, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ```{.python .cell-code} type(df["Math"]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} # ## DataFrame df[["Math"]] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Math s1 99 s2 65 s3 87 ``` ::: ```{.python .cell-code} type(df[["Math"]]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} df[["Math", "CS"]] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Math CS s1 99 50 s2 65 88 s3 87 94 ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: ::: notes isinstance(df[["Math"]], pd.DataFrame) ::: ## Subsetting Rows `DataFrame.iloc` - **integer-location** based indexing for selection by position :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Math Stat CS s1 99 92 50 s2 65 48 88 s3 87 88 94 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} ## first row Series df.iloc[0] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Math 99 Stat 92 CS 50 Name: s1, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} ## first row DataFrame df.iloc[[0]] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Math Stat CS s1 99 92 50 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} ## first 2 rows df.iloc[[0, 1]] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Math Stat CS s1 99 92 50 s2 65 48 88 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} ## 1st and 3rd row df.iloc[[True, False, True]] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Math Stat CS s1 99 92 50 s3 87 88 94 ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: ## Subsetting Rows and Columns `DataFrame.iloc` :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Math Stat CS s1 99 92 50 s2 65 48 88 s3 87 88 94 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} ## (1, 3) row and (1, 3) col df.iloc[[0, 2], [0, 2]] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Math CS s1 99 50 s3 87 94 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} ## all rows and 1st col df.iloc[:, [True, False, False]] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Math s1 99 s2 65 s3 87 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} df.iloc[0:2, 1:3] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Stat CS s1 92 50 s2 48 88 ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: ## Subsetting Rows and Columns `DataFrame.loc` Access a group of rows and columns by **label(s)** :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Math Stat CS s1 99 92 50 s2 65 48 88 s3 87 88 94 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} df.loc['s1', "CS"] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 50 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} ## all rows and 1st col df.loc['s1':'s3', [True, False, False]] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Math s1 99 s2 65 s3 87 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} df.loc['s2', ['Math', 'Stat']] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Math 65 Stat 48 Name: s2, dtype: int64 ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: ## Obtain a Single Cell Value `DataFrame.iat`/ `DataFrame.at` :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Math Stat CS s1 99 92 50 s2 65 48 88 s3 87 88 94 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} df.iat[1, 2] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 88 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} df.iloc[0].iat[1] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 92 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} df.at['s2', 'Stat'] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 48 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} df.loc['s1'].at['Stat'] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 92 ``` ::: ::: ::: :::: ## New Columns `DataFrame.insert` and New Rows `pd.concat` :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Math Stat CS s1 99 92 50 s2 65 48 88 s3 87 88 94 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} df.insert(loc = 2, column = "Chem", value = [77, 89, 76]) df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Math Stat Chem CS s1 99 92 77 50 s2 65 48 89 88 s3 87 88 76 94 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: {.fragment} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} df1 = pd.DataFrame({ "Math": 88, "Stat": 99, "Chem": 0, "CS": 100 }, index = ['s4']) ``` ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} pd.concat(objs = [df, df1], ignore_index = True) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Math Stat Chem CS 0 99 92 77 50 1 65 48 89 88 2 87 88 76 94 3 88 99 0 100 ``` ::: ::: ::: ::: :::: # {background-color="#ffde57" background-image="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/31/NumPy_logo_2020.svg" background-size="50%"} ::: {.left}

NumPy

::: ## NumPy - **NumPy** is used to work with arrays/matrices. - The array object in NumPy is called `ndarray`. - Use `array()` to create an array. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} import numpy as np range(0, 5, 1) # a seq of number from 0 to 4 with increment of 1 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` range(0, 5) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} arr = np.array(range(0, 5, 1)) ## One-dim array print(arr) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [0 1 2 3 4] ``` ::: ```{.python .cell-code} print(type(arr)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` ``` ::: ::: . . . `np.arange`: Efficient way to create a one-dim array of sequence of numbers ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} np.arange(8) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` array([0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]) ``` ::: ::: ## 2D Array (Matrix) and 3D Array ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} np.array([[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` array([[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]]) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} np.array([[[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]], [[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]]]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` array([[[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]], [[1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6]]]) ``` ::: ::: ## `np.reshape()` ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} arr2 = np.arange(8).reshape(2, 4) arr2 ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` array([[0, 1, 2, 3], [4, 5, 6, 7]]) ``` ::: ```{.python .cell-code} arr2.shape ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` (2, 4) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} arr2.ndim ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 2 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} arr2.size ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` 8 ``` ::: ::: ## Stacking Arrays ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} a = np.array([1, 2, 3, 4]).reshape(2, 2) b = np.array([5, 6, 7, 8]).reshape(2, 2) np.vstack((a, b)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` array([[1, 2], [3, 4], [5, 6], [7, 8]]) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} np.hstack((a, b)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` array([[1, 2, 5, 6], [3, 4, 7, 8]]) ``` ::: ::: ## :::{.lab} **09-NumPy and pandas** In **lab.qmd** `## Lab 9` section, create a Python pandas.DataFrame equivalent to the R tibble ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} tibble(x = 1:5, y = 5:1, z = LETTERS[1:5]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 5 Ã— 3 x y z 1 1 5 A 2 2 4 B 3 3 3 C 4 4 2 D 5 5 1 E ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.python .cell-code} import numpy as np import pandas as pd import string list(string.ascii_uppercase) dic = {'__': ____________, '__': reversed(____________), '__': list(string.ascii_uppercase)[______]} pd._____________(dic) ``` ::: ::: ## Lab Bonus! - Happy Valentine's Day! â¤ï¸ ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- seq(0, 2*pi, by = 0.01) xhrt <- 16 * sin(x) ^ 3 yhrt <- 13 * cos(x) - 5 * cos(2*x) - 2 * cos(3*x) - cos(4*x) par(mar = c(0, 0, 0, 0)) plot(xhrt, yhrt, type = "l", axes = FALSE, xlab = "", ylab = "") polygon(xhrt, yhrt, col = "red", border = NA) points(c(10,-10, -15, 15), c(-10, -10, 10, 10), pch = 169, font = 5) text(0, 0, "Happy Valentine's Day!", font = 2, cex = 2, col = "pink") ``` ::: ## <script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
